     Head I  -  Ministry of Community Development, Youth and Sports (cont.)  -

 

     Resumption of Debate on Question [10th March, 2005],

     That the total sum to be allocated for Head I of the Estimates be reduced by $100."  -  [Mr Sin Boon Ann].

 

     Question again proposed.

     The Minister of State for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon): Sir, yesterday, I shared the passion and compassion of hon. Members when they expressed their views to help needy Singaporeans.  A number of Members, including Mr Sin Boon Ann and Mr Wee Siew Kim, have raised concerns on the needy, and would like to know how the ComCare Fund will help such Singaporeans. Dr Warren Lee and Miss Penny Low wanted to know how the ComCare Fund will work in practice.

 

     The Government is committed to do more for needy Singaporeans, to ensure that no one will be left behind. The Prime Minister had announced the ComCare Fund in January this year.  The ComCare Fund will allow us to do the following:

 

     (a) Introduce new programmes to better help needy Singaporeans.

 

     (b) Give us the flexibility in helping needy Singaporeans in an effective and efficient manner.

 

     (c) Allow the Government to work closely with our community partners to develop new and creative programmes that help address the needs identified at the community, as they know best how assistance should be channelled.

 

     The ComCare Fund will be the core of our social safety net.  As my Minister, Dr Vivian Balakrishnan, had explained yesterday, the ComCare Fund will be based on three principles:

 

     Fostering self-reliant individuals;

     Family as the first line of support;  and

Column: 2444

     "Many Helping Hands".


     The ComCare Endowment Fund will start with $500 million and have a target size of $1 billion. This is a large sum. ComCare will provide up to $55 million a year for assistance schemes as a start.  This is 40% more than what MCYS is projected to spend on social assistance in FY2004.  On the other hand, the money will be spent very quickly if we use the money as hand-outs and try to help every Singaporean meet every need.  We know that the money must be spent prudently and wisely. We are not a welfare state. Our approach is to provide assistance, so that people can become self-reliant and not be dependent on the state.  

 

     While the Government will play an important role in the social safety net, we need ordinary citizens, Community Development Councils (CDCs), voluntary welfare organisations, and grassroots organisations to also help hold up this social safety net. They are in the best position to develop creative programmes that will help us build a strong, robust net that can serve our people. 


     On its part, the Government will take a focused and coordinated approach to assist needy Singaporeans.  Today, I will elaborate on how we intend to achieve the objectives of the ComCare Fund while keeping in mind the three key principles of our social safety net.

 

     The desired outcomes of the ComCare Fund are, first, to enable needy families to tide over difficult times and make a living for themselves.  Second, we want to make the social safety net simpler to understand and administer it more efficiently. 

 

     The ComCare Fund will help those families who have genuine difficulties making ends meet. We will therefore continue to means-test all applicants for assistance. We will also factor in the

Column: 2445

family's needs and special circumstances, their savings, and their support network of family and friends. 

 

     We will take a client-centric approach towards helping needy families. As my Minister has mentioned, ComCare will comprise three key components, each covering a specific client group.  These components are ComCare SelfReliance, ComCare Grow, and ComCare EnAble.  Let me elaborate.


     ComCare SelfReliance will focus on those who need some temporary assistance in order to return to self-reliance.  Programmes under this component target Singaporeans who are out of work, or who face temporary financial difficulties.  Existing programmes such as the Work Assistance Programme (WAP), Self-Reliance Programme (SReP) and Home Ownership Plus Education (HOPE) Scheme will come under ComCare SelfReliance.  Possible new programmes include those that help to develop social enterprises which provide needy Singaporeans secure a job. We will also look into helping them set up informal micro enterprises. 
 

     With ComCare SelfReliance, there will be a closer linkage between social assistance and job assistance. We have already moved in this direction starting with the Work Assistance Programme introduced on 1st October 2003. We will build on the experience we have gained, to develop other programmes that can help needy families in a sustainable manner. We expect to spend $17 million on ComCare SelfReliance programmes in FY2005.

 

     ComCare Grow, the second component, will aim to help children from low income families. We want the children to be better able to cope with mainstream education, and break out of the poverty cycle. A recent study by James Heckman, winner of the Nobel Prize for Economics in

Column: 2446

year 2000, confirmed that gaps in abilities among children from various socio-economic groups open up at early ages. The family plays an important role in shaping these abilities. Programmes that target young children from disadvantaged families have the greatest economic and social returns.
 

     ComCare Grow programmes will, therefore, help children access developmental programmes from a young age. Existing developmental programmes such as the Kindergarten Financial Assistance Scheme (KiFAS), Centre-Based Financial Assistance Scheme for Childcare (CFAC), and the Student Care Fee Assistance Scheme (SCFA) will come under the ComCare Grow umbrella.  MCYS will be reviewing these programmes to ensure that the social safety net for these children will be wide enough to catch them before they fall too far.  We will also look at new programmes that can be introduced.  Dr John Chen's suggestion during the Budget debate to provide money for transport and food to needy children is something that we can examine.


     Children from "at-risk" families need more targeted assistance to ensure that they start off on the right footing.  This will be done under the ComCare Grow umbrella through the Healthy Start Programme.  Healthy Start is a holistic early intervention programme for children from "at-risk" families as well as their parents.  It provides the family and the child with mentoring and counselling in addition to subsidies for pre-school support. We tried out Healthy Start as a pilot programme with Ang Mo Kio Family Service Centre and Beyond Social Services. The results were encouraging. 78% of the children improved their development level. The net monthly household income increased for 32% of the families.  MCYS will therefore be expanding the Healthy Start Programme in FY2005.  We will target 1,200 children in FY2005, up from the 350

Column: 2447

children that participated in the pilot programme. We expect to spend $24 million on ComCare Grow programmes in FY2005.


     The third component of the ComCare Fund, ComCare EnAble, will focus on the needy elderly, as well as others who need long term assistance in order to integrate into the community. ComCare EnAble will therefore also cater to the disabled, and the destitute chronic poor. ComCare EnAble programmes will include existing long-term social assistance schemes such as Public Assistance and Special Grant Schemes, programmes that reach out to the elderly living alone, and means-tested programmes to support families that have to take care of the frail elderly. 

 

     Yesterday, my Minister had announced the enhancements to the Assistive Technology Fund (ATF). Assistance technology is a powerful enabler for persons with disability to overcome their disability and integrate into society. ATF will come under ComCare EnAble.  With the changes to the ATF, about 1,150 persons with disability will be able to benefit from the scheme.  We expect to spend $14 million on ComCare EnAble programmes in FY2005.

 

     Dr Warren Lee, Miss Penny Low and Dr Tan Boon Wan asked about the modus operandi for the ComCare Fund. There will be fundamental changes in social assistance administration.  We will take a holistic, flexible, decentralised and partnership approach.

 

     Dr Tan Boon Wan asked about treating needy families holistically. In implementing ComCare programmes, we will take into consideration the holistic needs of the family. Many families who need the social safety net face multiple issues.  It is not effective to take a piecemeal approach to helping them.  Instead, their needs should be looked into holistically,

Column: 2448

so that a better solution, which covers all their needs, is provided. 


     I agree with Mr Sin Boon Ann that we should simplify social assistance schemes.  However, I want to emphasise that simplification must not result in one-size-fits-all solution. We recognise that there are some people who truly need assistance, but may not fit the eligibility criteria of our schemes.  ComCare Fund aims to address such cases by providing flexibility in the administration of social assistance. 

 

     Therefore, while the nationwide ComCare schemes will still be subject to MCYS guidelines, and will remain means-tested, the CDCs will be given the flexibility to provide assistance to genuinely needy cases that do not fit the eligibility criteria. In determining whether and how to provide assistance, the CDCs will take into account all the circumstances that the needy family face. This will help ensure that no needy Singaporean or family will fall through any gaps.  


     We intend to decentralise the administration of social assistance to the community. The CDCs have done good work in administering social assistance schemes with the help of advisors and grassroots leaders. The processing time has improved, with 73% of cases being processed within six weeks. There is however room for improvement. On Wednesday, Minister of Health, Mr Khaw Boon Wan,

had quoted Alexandra Hospital's experiment with the Toyota Production System which has helped reduce waiting time.  We, too, will be watching the Alexandra Hospital's "Toyota" experiment with great interest.

 

12.15 pm


     The CDCs have also developed local assistance schemes to meet the specific needs of their residents. For example, the

Column: 2449

North-East CDC has a Home Care Assist Programme, which helps the needy ill or bed-bound elderly by providing them with homecare items, home modifications, transport for follow-up care, and medical equipment.  Central-Singapore CDC has developed a RiDE scheme, which provides transport subsidies to needy residents who attend activities at selected day care centres. North-West CDC has a Food Ration scheme which provides food rations to needy residents.  South-East CDC has organised Edu Assist 2004 for needy students in their district.  South-West CDC has food vouchers for those who need short-term assistance.

 

     CDC officers and grassroots leaders are closer to the residents and have better understanding of their family circumstances. They are better able to customise the assistance according to their residents' needs.  With the ComCare Fund, we will empower the CDCs to do even more.

 

     The CDCs will need to strengthen their links with their community partners, such as grassroots organisations and VWOs, so that they can deliver assistance to needy residents more effectively, and those who need help know where to go.  This is what I call a "people to people" approach, with people sector organisations helping the people.  The "many helping hands" have each its own unique capabilities and strengths. It is only when society marshals its resources that we can effectively help needy families. 


     MCYS will support the CDCs in the administration of the ComCare Fund by providing the necessary resources.  Dr Lily Neo had asked about a register for the destitute.

 

     MCYS will take the lead to develop a centralised database that will capture the essential data of all social assistance beneficiaries. We will look into linking this database with other Ministries which also

Column: 2450

deal with the needy.  We will also work with VWOs and grassroots organisations to contribute to this database. This database will help to ensure that there is coordinated assistance for needy Singaporeans. 
 

     I agree with Mdm Cynthia Phua and Miss Penny Low that social workers play a critical role in helping  needy families. My Ministry will help to enhance the capability of these social service professionals. In 2002, we had set up a $30 million VWO Capability Fund.  We will use this fund to enhance the capability of VWOs as well as social workers.  We will do this through upgrading professional standards, training staff, piloting new services, and helping VWOs adopt systems and technology that help social workers in their work.

 

      MCYS has also introduced scholarships and the Strategic Manpower Conversion Programme to attract more people to become social work professionals.  55 people have joined these programmes since 2003.  In the coming year, we will do more to increase the take-up rate of these programmes.


     I will be chairing a Supervisory Committee, which will consist of the five CDC Mayors, the Permanent Secretary of MCYS, Chief Executive Director of People's Association, the President of NCSS and, more importantly, we are inviting a few leaders from VWOs. 

 

     The role of the Supervisory Committee will be to initiate, coordinate and monitor all ComCare programmes. The Supervisory Committee has a lot to do. It will review existing social assistance schemes and simplify them.  Overlapping resource allocations between schemes will be reduced.  It will ensure that needy Singaporeans are able to understand the schemes, and that they know where to turn to when they need help.
 

Column: 2451

      As the Supervisory Committee has only just been set up, it would need time to meet and identify its priorities. Miss Penny Low and Mdm Cynthia Phua have asked what are the KPIs and timeframes for the ComCare Fund. These are things which the Committee will be looking into.  I can assure the House that there will be proper KPIs, and a proper system of accountability and transparency for the funds that will be spent.

 

     The needs of Singaporeans will not be static. They will evolve, even as our society and economy continue to change. We have to ensure that Singapore's social capability to help needy Singaporeans grows and evolves to keep pace with the changing needs of Singaporeans.  The ComCare Fund is an important vehicle in this context.  It will help to ensure that even as Singapore undergoes economic restructuring and reaches for higher economic growth amidst stiffer global competition, no needy Singaporean or family is left behind.

 

     Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied): Sir, I  want to make a point of clarification with the Minister of State.  She mentioned that 75% of the cases are processed within six weeks.  What does she mean by "processed within six weeks"?  In fact, this morning I have just gone through the list of the cases in my division.  I have 105 cases. Out of 105, 93 cases are either pending investigation or recommendation, which means that less than 10% has been decided. That is a very low percentage. 

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: For social assistance cases, when an MP appeals to the Mayor and CDC - I was a Mayor before and based on my experience - let me explain how the CDC operates.  Like I said, the Supervisory Committee needs to give more resources to also train the staff to do the job better and to deliver.  But I feel that a strong message to get across

Column: 2452

today is that for the ComCare Fund, we will take a "people-to-people" approach. What I hope to see is that the CCCs, RCs and the advisors can work together to help the CDCs to investigate the case faster and decide whether the case is a genuine case.  In that way, we can help the social workers to speed up their decision.

 

     According to the feedback and report from my Ministry, for 78% of the cases, they have processed them in less than six weeks.  Some of the cases are quite straightforward and obvious.  So I am sure they can handle them within one week.  In some cases where they need long-term financial help, the commitment is more long term.  They would need to go and visit them.  I understand that sometimes, when they sent letters to them, they could not get a reply, or even when they called them, they also could not get a reply.  There are many reasons why they need six weeks, or more than six weeks.  Anyway, what I am trying to say is that there is room for improvement.  The most effective way we want to see from the ComCare Fund is that the Ministry will work together with the CDCs, CCCs, RCs and the advisors.

     Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Sir, can I ask that the Ministry consider setting a service benchmark for the CDCs, in terms of the response time in relation to the requests to appeal for financial and social assistance?  From my own experience, sometimes, I do know that the CDCs may take a while to investigate.  But from the recipients' point of view, they are very often left in the dark.  If there is a seemingly lack of response, it would make it seem as if CDCs are not doing their work properly.  So if you set a service standard, a certain benchmark, at least it becomes more transparent in the way in which services are delivered by the agencies, such as the CDCs.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: Sir, like I said, the Supervisory Committee has just been

Column: 2453

set up.  Definitely, my working committee will look into the procedures, like KPIs and accountability and, as suggested by Mr Sin Boon Ann, how to set a benchmark.  I think we need to look into all these areas to improve the communication.

     Miss Penny Low (Pasir Ris-Punggol): I also want to highlight that, while we look towards working with the CCCs and the grassroots organisations for their support in the scheme itself, which I certainly encourage, I must also point out that they are all volunteers and, therefore, relying or counting on them alone will not be enough. 

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: Miss Penny Low touched on a very important point.  Besides the grassroots and the advisors, the VWO is a very important wing.  So far, the Family Service Centres are all very supportive.  We will definitely work with the VWOs.

     Dr Teo Ho Pin (Holland-Bukit Panjang): Sir, I want to clarify about the service benchmark for CDCs.  CDCs do set a certain standard, in terms of delivery of social service, which is six weeks, and most of the time we are able to achieve that. But most of the time, the delay is because the recipient is not responding to the CDC.  That is one thing which we have to bring the message across.  It is the responsibility of the client also to make an effort to contact the CDC.  It is not a one way communication.  It is a two-way communication in order to reach out to the needy.  This is to clarify her point.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua: Sir, I would like to again reconfirm that for the six weeks of processing, we must definitely make a decision, whether we want to give the first help and then continue with the other help.  But there must be a KPI on that part itself, and not the processing time.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: Sir, I have mentioned just now that we are giving flexibility to the CDCs.  They may have cases which are very urgent. The Mayor and advisors should make a decision that we should give some interim help. It must depend on the background of the case.  Like I said, we will take a holistic approach to look into the circumstances of the case.

     Mdm Cynthia Phua: There is one more point.  Ninety-five cases out of 105 cases currently pending in my division is a very high percentage.  So it is not a matter of one or two urgent cases.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: Who is the Mayor?  What I am trying to say here is that we will feed back and work immediately with the Mayors and the advisors.  I am sure Mdm Cynthia Phua will definitely want to work with us and sort out these problems immediately.

     The Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed): Sir, since the Mayor's name has been invoked, I would like to reassure Mdm Phua that, in fact, we treat all cases with urgency.  For those cases which are very urgent, especially those that came from MPS cases, we give special attention to it, and we will reply to the MP concerned.  For MPs who are still not happy with the rate of processing and rate of reply, they should bring this up directly to the Mayor concerned, and we would give due attention.

Voluntary Welfare Organisations

 

     Dr Chong Weng Chiew (Tanjong Pagar):  Sir, it is not easy to read fast, and I have to apologise for it.  First, allow

Column: 2455

me to declare my interest in a few charity welfare organisations.

 

     VWOs are central to our "many helping hands" approach to welfare delivery.  There are two groups of VWOs: those run by secular groups and those supported by religious groups.  Both have their places in our community complementing one another.  However, while VWOs with religious connections enjoy the continued patronage and support of their various congregations, non-religious VWOs do not have such an advantage.

 

      A recent national survey commissioned by the National Volunteer and Philanthropy Centre found that 52% of donations made by individuals between April 2003 and 2004 went to churches, temples, mosques and other places of worship.  A proportion of these donations are in turn used to fund community projects and VWOs supported by religious groups.  Hence, all the more our secular VWOs need the Government support to carry out the mission and tasks effectively. Because they are secular, they are not restricted by guidelines inherent in VWOs linked to religious groups, and thus can work together with all groups in our multi-religious, multi-cultural community to reach broad based targets.

Racial Harmony

 

     Mr Alexander Chan Meng Wah (Nominated Member):  Sir, in many multi-ethnic societies around the world, recent world events and terrorism have definitely caused some stresses and strains on inter-communal relations, whether covert or overt.  Multi-racial Singapore was not spared

nor insulated from such terrorist threat developments.  We had our share

Column: 2456

of tests and near misses.  If any of the JI plans had happened, for example, Singapore could have suffered an unpredictably protracted period of difficult race relations.  Protected by a Constitution, Singapore today has a good history of peaceful community life recognising our multi-ethnicity, multi-cultural heritage and multi-language and multi-religious nature.  Today, we have a number of organisations, eg, self-help groups that are specifically race-based and function to serve only within their own community.  The logic of this is that each community is best able to deal with her own kind.  While we can easily understand the merits of this logic, I feel that in addition to some benefits, we may also have, by such design, created the organisational and administrative boundaries and interstices between such groups. 

 

     We recently started to debate the issue of lack of Malay language skills, for example, made evident during the humanitarian efforts in Banda Aceh.  In the workplace, we can easily observe that people tend to congregate among their own races, eg, Chinese lunch with Chinese, Malays with Malays.  This is, of course, natural.  And, in Singapore, there may not be anything insidious about such behaviour.  Nevertheless, we have somewhat diminished the fact of having English be one type of social inter-racial glue in everyday life.  Sir, my point is that, by our well-intended policies to improve our proficiencies in our mother tongue, we have concomitantly traded off the benefits of having English as a common working language. 

 

     Similarly, I anticipate that the formation of more ethic-based self-help groups could also inadvertently have other consequences only because it becomes administratively convenient for policy implementation, because we now have a reporting label and a mail box.  It is quite common for official reports and for the media to report things using our convenient racial sort of criteria, eg,

Column: 2457

smoking incident, school results, crime statistics.  Again, we are all cognisant that this was not the original intent.  But once conveniences become available, they do become easily too convenient.  So, there seems to be a need to find more opportunities and social glue, both public and private sector NGOs, to offer cross-racial boundary activities that further bind our society. 

 

     My questions, therefore, are:  How does MCYS keep a pulse on these matters? What is the state of race relations deep down?  And what are our future strategies for improving race relations further, beyond campaigns?

     The Chairman:  Mr David Lim is not here.  Miss Penny Low.  Two minutes.

would also like to ask the Minister if he has plans to work with the STB for bringing in key sports events to fire up the enthusiasm of younger Singaporeans.

Casinos

 

     Dr Geh Min (Nominated Member):  Sir, I would like to ask if reliable studies have been done on the social impact and cost of gambling, especially casino gambling, in and on Singapore.  In order to see the big picture, we cannot just look at the bright side - tourist dollars, increased revenue - but the dark side, as depicted by the tragedy of Simon Lee and his family.

 

     Studies done abroad show great variation from country to country and even community to community.  And this makes it imperative that we do our own studies rather than rely on others.  What is the estimated size of the problem?   What are the groups at risk?  We cannot assume that just because people have gambling in their blood that they are automatically immune to the side effects.  I know that reliable data is not easy to collect or quantify and that much of the social impact of problem gambling is indirect, insidious and long term.  Even if 

Column: 2461

it is identified, the costs are likely to be under-estimated.  For example, how do you quantify the loss of work ethic or family dysfunction until it reaches breaking point?  These, to me, are all reasons for doing systematic studies of the social impacts of problem gambling as soon as accurately and as exhaustively as possible.

 

     For instance, can the recent rise in child abuse, divorce and bankruptcies that we have read about be related to an increase in pathological gambling?  The Prime Minister has stated quite correctly, and I agree with him, that the role of Government is to risk-manage, not to risk-eliminate; to provide a safety net, but not a security blanket.  But may I say that where the safety net is positioned is crucial.  And the best way to risk-manage is to anticipate problems and prevent them, if possible.  If not, at least treat them at source.  Of course, the worst is to let them balloon out of all proportion.  I am sure the Government does not intend to do that.  Therefore, we should have reliable data of the social cost of gambling, particularly casino gambling, which I believe is more addictive. 

 

     In Singapore, in order to help us decide whether we should have a casino, what form it should take, what social safeguards to have, and where they can be most effectively placed, may I say here I do not agree that they should just be placed at the casino itself.  They should be placed on the community level and, most importantly, how we can best manage the social costs that arise.  Most of these costs and impacts will be borne by the family and community.  We should therefore be given an idea of what they are likely to be, how we can manage them, how we can contain them and, best of all, how we can minimise their impact.

     The Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan): Sir, yesterday I focused on

Column: 2462

the first priority of our Ministry, which was to ensure that all Singaporeans have opportunities to maximise his or her potential and that no one would be left behind.  Let me now focus on the second area, which is to nurture the relationships that make life in Singapore meaningful and worthwhile.  That is what binds us together as family members, as members of our community, as fellow citizens, and it is the nature of these relationships that make Singapore our home.  That is why we are interested in issues like the family, that is why we are concerned with volunteerism, philanthropy, the state of racial harmony, sports and many other things that Members have brought up in the last hour. 

 

     Many Singaporeans derive a great sense of fulfilment when they are able to look beyond themselves and to do something for the community.  They make a real difference to the lives of the people they come into contact with, and we need to encourage and nurture this spontaneous willingness, this expression of their heart to do more and to make a difference.  That is why we have adopted this many-helping-hands approach, in which we will work with individuals, companies and voluntary welfare organisations to promote volunteerism and charity work and to encourage all of them to come forward. 

 

     I want to say at this point in response to Dr Chong Weng Chiew that I am agnostic as to whether a voluntary welfare organisation is religious or secular as far as its primary motivations are concerned.  But what we do insist on is that they express this willingness to serve in a manner which does not discriminate on the basis of race, language or religion.  That is why Members of the House will be aware that, in order to get an Institution of Public Character (IPC) status which then enables the donors to claim double tax relief, the work that that organisation performs must be delivered in a race,

Column: 2463

language and religion-neutral fashion.  So, I think with that framework in place, we can afford to be flexible and, frankly, to encourage all organisations, regardless of whether they are secular or religious, to carry on performing their social services.  Indeed, I want to encourage them to do a lot more. 

 

     This general approach of supporting organisations, and of supporting and encouraging Singaporeans to contribute their time, energy and efforts has actually paid off in a very real and significant way.  If we look at the figures, from 1998 to 2003, donations to IPCs have doubled, and the figure is now more than $500 million a year.  If you look at volunteerism rates, that has also increased from 9.3% in 2000 to 15.2%

last year.  This is an increase, and I am sure we can do more and we certainly want to encourage Singaporeans to volunteer even more.

     But if we needed any further proof that Singaporeans have a big heart, we only need to look at the spontaneous and tremendous outpouring of compassion, help and donations that were manifested by Singaporeans during the recent tsunami disaster.  We need no longer have any doubts in our mind that Singapore and Singaporeans are generous and compassionate people with a very big heart. 

 

     We will continue to expand capabilities in the people sector.  Voluntary welfare organisations, although you say "voluntary", they do need to be professional as well.  We need to enhance the professionalism of both the volunteers as well as the paid staff of these organisations.  That is why the  NCSS has been working with VWOs to enhance training for social service personnel and also to help them take advantage, for instance, of the capabilities with increased

Column: 2464

use of info-communications technology (ICT) for these VWOs.  We want VWOs to also move up and make use of all the training and facilities which are available in the modern world. 

 

    But there is another aspect, which again was illustrated by our response to the tsunami disaster.  That was the fact that VWOs could do so much more by collaborating with each other and by pursuing mutual synergy.  That is why I was very heartened that one of the key committees that arose was this Tsunami Reconstruction Facilitation Committee.  Yes, it is led by the Red Cross which, after all, raised about $81 million.  But it has representatives from a wide spectrum of VWOs who were involved and engaged in the efforts to assist these victims.   The Committee embodies the premise that we can do so much more by working with each other. And it is also noteworthy that if you look at the actual organisations that were on the ground, we saw organisations, which may have started on, which were religious.  But coming together, we had Muslim, Buddhist and Christian organisations being able to come together, worked together and very often, even have a common front.  In that way, they actually carried the Singapore flag very high for all of us.  We could all celebrate and be happy that we were able to show that in Singapore, when we say, regardless of race, language and religion, we have actually taken this one step further.  We are able to work together to achieve so much more.  This, I believe is another reason for us to celebrate.

 

    Let me turn to the issues on youth.  Last year, my Ministry was renamed the Ministry of Community Development, Youth and Sports.  As some of you have said, this cannot just be a name change.  It demonstrates the Government's commitment to engage  youth of Singapore in our efforts to shape our common future.  My hope is that every young Singaporean will be able to proudly say, at some point

Column: 2465

in time in the future, that he has made a difference to some corner, some community, some people or to some cause in Singapore.  Because he or she will be able to say, "I had a role to play and I made it, and I helped shape it in that way."  Then, that sense of ownership, pride, belonging and engagement will be entrenched and enhanced.  We are now in a world in which ownership can no longer be just defined by owning a piece of concrete, a flat or even a home.  I think young Singaporeans nowadays define ownership in terms of the intangible dimension. That intangible dimension is the opportunity to contribute and to make a difference.

 

    Some people have said and falsely accused young Singaporeans of being apathetic.  Last year, we launched a nation-wide consultation exercise.  The first order of the day in my Ministry was to launch this exercise and say, "Look, if we are going to address and engage our youth, the first thing we better do is to listen to them."  My Parliamentary Secretary, Dr Maliki, Miss Penny Low and Dr Chong Weng Chiew were intimately involved in leading this consultation exercise.  Dr Maliki will give Members a few more details later. But what did we learn from this exercise? 

 

    First, young Singaporeans are not apathetic.  Second, there is a large reservoir of goodwill, enthusiasm, passion and energy out there, waiting to be tapped and  unleashed so that they can make a difference to this home that we call Singapore.  Because young people do not know what can go wrong or they do not know the limits, that very ignorance gives young people the liberation to have no limits to their imagination.  I think older Singaporeans need to give space to these unbridled enthusiasm and imagination of young people.  Consequently, our challenge is not to tell young people that their idea cannot be done, it does not work or we have tried it before and it had

Column: 2466

failed.  Our challenge is to say, "If you got an idea, now take it on to the next step. Translate it into action.  Make it come to reality."  In that process of translating it into action, young people will discover what can or cannot work, whether it makes sense or does not make sense.  In that process of discovery, they will learn the real lessons of life and, ultimately, make a difference to our society.  It is also possible that in this journey of discovery, they will discover some decisions which we had assumed were correct in the past, perhaps  no longer apply today.  And the young people may genuinely come up with better solutions than we have had in the past. 

 

    We are going to be guided by four principles in our engagement with young Singaporeans. First, we want to empower our young Singaporeans. That means, I am not going to prescribe to them, I am not going to dictate to them, I am not going to tell them what to do nor am I going to hold their hands throughout this journey of discovery. We will play a facilitative and a nurturing role.  We will provide opportunities and support but it is up to the young Singaporeans to direct their talents and energy in the directions that they wish to go, whatever those directions are.

 

     Second, we will embrace the diversity that young Singaporeans bring to the table. Young Singaporeans are a very heterogeneous lot with very different interests. Some have a very good heart, and they want to help the less fortunate.  Others are interested in preserving the environment, while others in arts, sports, culture, in mentoring others, and so on.  We need to recognise and celebrate this diversity and let them decide, for each young Singaporean, what he or she wants to do.

 

    Third, we must be inclusive. Our youths come from varied backgrounds and have different needs. Some may be disabled or from less fortunate back

Column: 2467

grounds or be at risk because they are out of school or facing difficult social circumstances. They will need our help in order for them to realise their potential.  But we must focus beyond their problems and be able to look instead at the potential for each young Singaporean.  Therefore, we must focus on giving them opportunities.  It does not matter whether a person has failed academically or has taken an unconventional route. Always look at what opportunities lie in front of that person and our job is to give them a chance - to give them a second, third, fourth or fifth chance. 

 

     Finally, we must ensure that even as we exhort young Singaporeans to contribute to society, we must also make sure they benefit from it.  I am quite glad that the Ministry of Education has done away with CCA points for JC students and even removed the need for a mandatory six hours of CIP for JC students.  Because now, they will do what they truly feel motivated to do.  Similarly, the voluntary organisations which use the services of these young Singaporeans will now understand that there must be mutual benefit. The young Singaporean must learn something from his engagement and participation in your enterprise. 

 

    I have asked for a handout to be distributed to Members. That is because many of you asked me what are our upcoming initiatives.  First of all, I want to say that I am really not embarrassed to say, if you look at the handout, there are about 10 different categories. The majority of the ideas in there were harvested from our youth consultation exercise. It shows you our sincerity.  It also shows you that we are going to give credit when credit is due.  I hope the thousands of young Singaporeans who have spent the last few months working day and night, furiously flashing out ideas,

Column: 2468

would now look at these plans and realise that they own these plans.

 

    Let me just quickly give you a flavour of what is contained in that handout.  First, the youth voice.  Many young Singaporeans have said that they want their voices to be heard. I agree with them. Fortunately for us, we were able to link some budding young writers with some enthusiastic editors in the Straits Times who were also quite coincidentally keen on starting a youth section, written by young people for young people.  Three months after the consultation exercise, we launched YouthInk, a weekly section in the Straits Times.

They are a very diverse batch - some doing NS and some are students in universities, polytechnics and ITEs.  If you have been reading their articles - and I hope Members of this House have been reading the articles that they have come up with - these are thinking, well-thought and considered opinions and perspectives that they are reflecting in those pages.  I hope this will continue as a permanent feature of our newspapers.

Column: 2469

fact, some strong criticisms of the views that were expressed by young Singaporeans taking part in the National Youth Forum.  I think it was a good learning experience for the young Singaporeans to realise that what they say does matter and not everyone is going to he happy, and not everyone is going to agree with what they say.  The decision making and policy formulation is a complex exercise, one in which they need to keep their ears open.  Ultimately, however, they have to take a position, make a decision and it does not mean everyone will always be happy.  I think it has been a very instructive lesson for all the young Singaporeans who had been  involved in the forum. 

 

     Next, we also wanted to tell them that, "Look, do not just confine yourself to writing, debating or discussing.  Go beyond words.  Translate your causes and your beliefs into action."  Again, in order to give young people a chance to translate things into action, we set up a Youth Portal.  This is a first-stop databank.  It is a databank and advisory service so that youths who wish to participate, whether their interest is in sports or environment or any cause that they want, would be able to see what organisations are out there, what needs are out there, what resources are available, how can they match that with their interest.

 

     Another initiative we will launch is a project called "Young Change Makers".  Basically, what we are going to do in this is to put some money aside, seed money for youth projects, but we would put young Singaporeans in charge of making the decisions as to which projects should be supported, which projects should not be supported.  This is peer review in action.  It will send several messages.  First, it will signal to young Singaporeans that we trust them.  We trust them to act responsibly when they are given resources to do so.  Secondly, for those who are coming up with ideas, they will now know they better come up with a good idea

Column: 2470

which passes muster and which convinces their peers and if the answer is no, do not just blame the people making the decision.  Usually, it is the Government having to say no to them and the usual excuse is to say, "Oh, the Government is being unsupportive, unhelpful, being obstructionist."  Now, they have to work with and convince their own peers.  There would, therefore, be a competition of ideas for these projects.

     The next thing I want to talk about is Orchard Road.  I have been fortunate to be in both MND and MTI and now in MCYS, and I have also chaired a committee which has spent the last one year cracking our minds as to how we are going to rejuvenate Orchard Road.  Over the last few days you have heard various Ministries made certain announcements with respect to Orchard Road.  Well, we have an "Orchard Road Announcement" for the youths.

MRT.  And, you would also be aware of the road closure that the LTA announced yesterday.  That allows us now to amalgamate 1.2 hectares of land right in the heart of the city, right in the heart of Orchard Road, in an area which has already been identified by the young as a place they want to hang out.  Now, it is not just going to be a hang-out place because we want this to be an iconic youth development, one in which not only our youths will come, but youths from all over the world and indeed tourists will say it is a must-see sight in Singapore.  How will we develop this?   The first thing is that we will get the views from young people.  What do they want to see there?  What activities do they want conducted there?  Then we will have to bring in architects, designers and the businesses as well to ensure that this place is commercially viable, exciting and interesting and, ultimately, contributes to the overall attractions that Orchard Road will have.  So our youths will have now a piece of land they can call their own, truly a space of their own.

Column: 2472

way to make a decent living, with self-respect, then these programmes would have achieved their objectives. 

 

     Let me now move on to sports as brought up by Mr Alex Chan.  Sir, we want Singaporeans from all races, cultures and backgrounds to interact, play, celebrate and bond together, and sports is one key modality to achieve that. Participation in sports also develops a healthy mind and body, quite apart from its impact on social interaction.  Supporting our national athletes and celebrating our sporting achievements have brought us closer together as a nation.

 

     On 16th January, our young Lions took on the Indonesian national soccer team in the Tiger Cup final.  I was there.  In fact, many Members of the House were there and I think we can all gladly report that the Kallang Roar was back, and is back with a vengeance.  All of us there were struck by this sense of collective purpose, the emotional unity that sports brings for all of us. 

 

     I also want to thank Mr Wee Siew Kim for his suggestion to work with STB to bring marquee sports events to Singapore.  The good news is that we already have a fair number of such events.  The one which I remember most obviously would be having the Singapore Marathon which was held in December last year.  Mr Ong Kian Min completed the full marathon.  I did 10 kilometres.  I am not sure whether this is going to be an occupational hazard or a bonus, but I suppose future Sports Ministers would have to run at least 10 kilometres.  But these marquee events really bring in more than just tourist dollars.  They do more than just put us on the map.  In the case of the marathon, we had about 15,000-16,000 people running.  The atmosphere was electric, that sense of oneness, that sense of conquering the challenge set out before you, and of achieving something for yourself and for your team, was incredible.  That is why

Column: 2473

we must continue to attract such sporting events and really push for greater participation.

 

     Mr Wee also asked about funding for sports.  In 2001, the Government, together with Singapore Pools, committed $500 million over a five-year period to a Sporting Singapore Fund.  In fact, this was brought about during Mr Speaker's tenure in the Ministry.  Part of this $500 million was used for infrastructure like the Sports School.  To build on this momentum, I am glad to announce that the Sporting Singapore Fund will receive an additional $300 million.  This $300 million would be utilised from 2006 to 2010, but the funding for the Sports Hub, which is going to cost an estimated sum of probably another $600-$650 million, will be separately funded.  So, I hope Members of this House will be assured that we are putting serious money aside to develop sports, sports infrastructure and a sporting culture in Singapore.

     In Singapore, our land resources are much more limited.  But we have tried, and are trying, to work around these constraints.  So there are two things which I want to announce today.  First, from next month, MCYS and MOE will open up a total of 50 school fields for public use.  We are going to call this the Dual-Use Scheme. 

 

Column: 2474

    Under this scheme, the schools will still have first right over the use of their fields, certainly during weekdays and on Saturday mornings.  But outside curriculum hours and on weekends, members of the public can book these fields for a small fee.  You can make your booking through the SSC website, and you can use these fields for any sports or recreational facilities.  The only thing I would appeal for is, please do not destroy the fields, do not damage the infrastructure.  Otherwise, you will set us back.  Assuming we get this implemented successfully, and 50 is only the tip of the iceberg, our intent is to expand this scheme to as many school fields as possible.

 

    Quite apart from school fields, we all know that there are patches of State land scattered throughout our island.  I am very glad that the Singapore Land Authority (SLA) last year started changing the signs.  Instead of saying "No Trespassing", they say, "Enter at your own risk", which is, I suppose, as much as you can hope from a legal perspective to say, "Come and use it if you like to."  

 

     Even as we open these pieces of land and we encourage informal play and free play on these pieces of land, I am sure there will be occasions when perhaps the grassroots organisations would look at this field and say, "Maybe we can improve it.  Fill in the potholes, so that you do not trip and break your ankle as you play football there."  What my Ministry will do is that we will set aside $2 million in a fund which grassroots organisations can apply for on a matching basis. I want a matching basis so that there is commitment.  So you identify a piece of land which you want to improve, you raise some funds, we will match your fund and you can then improve that piece of land to make it more playable, more attractive, so that your residents can use it.  And, of course, as I have said earlier, I

Column: 2475

want the use of this sort of informal facilities to be free.  I believe there is still a place for free facilities in Singapore, and this will help encourage the sporting culture, the mass participation that I spoke about.

 

     In addition to that, we will also continue to promote sports by focusing on the different demographic groups.  One of the key things is to focus on our young, because if you can get into a sporting habit early enough, then in effect you become addicted to exercise and it becomes a lifelong habit.  We will also work with more sports partners and the SSC would build on the successful Sports Partners Promotion programme, which subsidises private sports programme providers.  For example, there is a successful recreational soccer league, the ESPZEN, involving more than 40 teams, playing regularly throughout the year, supported by MCYS and the SSC.  SSC will further promote participation in sports through its comprehensive network of public sports facilities.

Sir, in his swearing-in speech last year,  Prime Minister Lee had called on young Singaporeans to "step forward to make a difference to yourselves, to your fellow citizens and to Singapore".  The "Youth: Creating Our Future" consultation exercise that MCYS launched in August last year was one major avenue through which we invited young Singaporeans to share their views, galvanise around causes they believe in, and influence the national agenda.  Miss Penny Low and Dr Chong Weng Chiew asked for an update of the consultation exercise.  I am pleased to share with Members the progress that MCYS has made so far.

 

     MCYS had launched the exercise to hear first-hand our youth's hopes, concerns and ideas so that we can enhance our policies and programmes for our youths. Over six weeks, we reached out to more than 2,000 youths from

Column: 2477

diverse backgrounds through multiple channels like SMS, focus groups and email.  My Ministry and other relevant Government agencies have been studying the wide-ranging inputs.  We plan to publish our responses next month.

 

     Some of the youths did not stop at giving feedback. They decided to turn their ideas into reality. One example, which my Minister had earlier mentioned, was how the weekly YouthInk section in the Straits Times had come about.

 

     Another group, comprising skateboarders, rollerbladers, mountain bikers who took part in the consultation exercise, decided to act on their own suggestion to raise awareness of extreme sports which have been gaining popularity amongst the young.  So we facilitated that interest.  They have planned two instalments of an event called soul to soul  -  the interesting name that they came out with  - to help promote the sports and discover home-grown talent.  The first was held in January this year as a warm-up exercise to gear them towards the larger scale event later this year.

 

     These and other examples convinced us that our young people are really not all NATO - "no action talk only" people.  Beyond giving feedback, many, given the opportunity, will take action and channel their energy into causes that they believe in.  It emboldened us to take the consultation exercise one step further by asking more of them to develop their ideas in greater depth.

 

     Sir, a few issues had cropped up repeatedly during the consultation. We decided to ask for volunteers among them to develop specific action plans and projects in these areas.  This, in essence, is really the bottoms-up approach that Miss Penny Low talked about.  120 of them stepped forward and formed four work groups.  One work group - called "Youth Action" - has been looking at

Column: 2478

enhancing opportunities for youth to volunteer and connect to community causes. Another group - they call themselves "Youth Connect" -  seeks to expand avenues to deepen youth engagement to the nation. A third group - "Youth Reloaded" - is developing proposals to support, empower and include youths who face greater challenges, such as youths at-risk and the disabled youth.  The final group, "Youth Biz", wants to nurture entrepreneurship among youth. 

 

     We facilitated their work by providing them access to civil servants who act as resource persons.  This allows the youths to appreciate policy making processes, as for the civil servants to appreciate the aspirations of the young.

 

     I have had the opportunity to interact with them and to preview their work.  As my Minister had said earlier, some of their inputs have shaped the Ministry's upcoming initiatives.  Let me share with Members my impressions of these work groups.


     First, I am struck by their conviction.  The youth involved are a diverse bunch, hailing from different backgrounds and life stages - from students, to working youths, to youths with disabilities.  Some had specific ideas to champion. Others wanted to change policies at the national level.  What they share however is a belief that Singapore can be a better place, and that they can contribute towards shaping this.

 

     It would have been hard for them to get the work groups going if they did not have this conviction.  Unlike many Government-initiated committees, the discussions, the idea generation and the report writing in the work groups are all led and done by the youths themselves, with guidance from the youth organisations who act as co-leaders.  MCYS deliberately took a backseat, acting only

Column: 2479

as resource persons.  I guess this is a fresh change for the civil servants.

 

     Many of the youths sacrificed late nights and weekends to volunteer their time.  I know of two groups that meet regularly on Saturdays or Sundays.  Ahmad Nizam, President of Mendaki Club and one of our work group co-chairmen, told me, "To the youths, it was not just a project, but a cause to them. They really believe in it. They went all out . . . Most of the time, we were trying to keep up with them."

 

     The second thing that impressed me was their broad outlook.  Many of their proposals are aimed at benefiting not only young people, but the wider community. For example, some of them are tackling big and complex issues such as improving the education and employment prospects and quality of life of people with disabilities.  


     Lastly, I am happy that the youths have a sense of ownership over their ideas, and are keen to follow through on some of them. Sure, many of their proposals are recommendations for the Government to consider and act on.  But there are also ideas that youths themselves want to champion and pursue, with some support if necessary.  

    

     The Youth Action work group had suggested the idea of a festival for young Singaporeans to celebrate and showcase their talent, energy and contribution.  This is to offer opportunities for all youths, youth organisations and community groups to initiate ground-up activities in a variety of areas that capture our youth's imagination, including arts, sports and adventure, community involvement, entrepreneurship and so on. Column: 2480

them to organise this festival, which will take place in the middle of this year.

     The work groups will release their reports soon.  I am confident that this will give the public a glimpse of the effort, enthusiasm and imagination that I have witnessed over the past few months.  The Ministries will study their proposals closely.  MCYS will track the status of the recommendations and communicate this regularly to the work group members.

     Sir, the specifics of the final recommendations aside, I think that the process of the exercise has been most valuable to both Government and the youth involved.  Let me explain why.

Column: 2481

Column: 2482

For example, rather than MCYS identifying the issues to be explored, we can consider ways to facilitate youths to initiate work groups on specific projects identified by youths themselves.

 

     Sir, our hope is that future youth work groups will widen the spectrum of engagement initiatives, together with the other initiatives that my Minister has mentioned earlier.  This is akin to sowing the seeds of opportunity, so that our youths and the nation can continue to bloom.
